page.title: 01North Staffs Neighbours
page.content: Newcastle-under-Lyme was granted its first charter by Henry II in 1173 and, with protection from the new castle from which its name comes, the town became the main route and market centre in North Staffordshire. Only a short, low section of wall from that castle remains. During the nineteenth century the towns of the nearby Potteries grew more rapidly. In 1910 the six separate towns of the Potteries joined a Federation and in 1925 this Federation of towns was granted the status of city by King George V. Newcastle-under-Lyme stoutly defends its independence from its larger neighbour although visitors to the area may not always be able to recognise where one ends and the other begins. They compete for new industries .
